citation.article-title: Characterization of filamentous Eikelboom type 021N bacteria and description of Thiothrix disciformis sp. nov. and Thiothrix flexilis sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Emended description of Thiothrix eikelboomii (Howarth et al. 1999)

The formal description remains that given by Howarth et al. (1999), with the following modifications. Volutin inclusions are observed in some strains; some strains grow with mannose, glycerol, xylose, propionate, aspartate and alanine; some strains may show slight growth with melibiose, raffinose and sorbitol; nitrate is reduced to nitrite by some strains. The following is added to the description of Howarth et al. (1999): Filaments are more than 0.5 mm long and can reach several millimetres. Colonies are fingerprint-like. Elongate and swollen cells are often present in filaments. Elongate cells in some strains sometimes reach 8 μm in length and swollen cells in some strains sometimes reach 8 μm in diameter. Septa are clearly visible between individual cells. Sudanophilic granules are observed densely within cells. Catalase-positive. Sulfuric acid is produced when cells are grown in the presence of a reduced inorganic sulfur compound. Butyrate, hydroxybutyrate and glutamate are utilized as sole carbon sources. No growth occurs with 1- propanol, ethanol, benzoate, formate or citrate. Growth is inhibited by 0.5% (w/v) NaCl. The G+C content of the DNA is 44-45 mol% (HPLC). The major quinone is UQ-8. The major fatty acids are C16:1, C16:0 and C18:1.
